abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Strengthening
            India's Rural Credit Cooperatives Project for India
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk
            to development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: a
            longer project timeframe could have been considered given
            the complexity and effort needed for reforming the
            cooperative sector in India. Governance reforms should be
            supplemented from the start with a very strong focus on
            enhancing credit risk management and recovery of
            non-performing loans. For ongoing monitoring and fine-tuning
            of the program, a stronger effort to collect, monitor and
            evaluate Primary Agricultural Credit Society (PACS) data at
            the central level is necessary. To improve governance and
            capacity, efforts have to be brought to the field and the
            cascading training approach provides a replicable model.
            Early involvement of the Bank in program design is
            important. Since members' (mostly farmers')
            demands are diverse, a project should consider different
            types of financial/non-financial services. Financial
            services involve not only credit, but also different
            products, such as savings and insurance. Close dialogue and
            strong coordination between the central and state
            governments are necessary. Members' education needs
            adequate attention to communicate program benefits to the
            ultimate beneficiary group. It is important that members
            understand the reform program and what the reform means to
            them. For a front-loaded governance reform program, a clear
            reporting framework on reform benchmark activities is
            critical. Country-based staff plays a key role in close
            monitoring, guidance and support during the project implementation.
